news_header: U.S. crude oil inventories rose significantly, exceeding expectations, while gasoline inventories increased slightly.
news_original_title: U.S. Crude Oil Inventories Surge Much More Than Expected
news_text: The Energy Information Administration reported a substantial increase in U.S. crude oil inventories, which rose by 8.7 million barrels for the week ending January 31st, following a 3.5 million barrel increase the previous week. Economists had anticipated a rise of only 3.2 million barrels. Current inventories stand at 423.8 million barrels, about 5% below the five-year average. Gasoline inventories also grew by 2.2 million barrels, slightly above the five-year average, while distillate fuel inventories, including heating oil and diesel, fell by 5.5 million barrels, approximately 12% below the five-year average.
